posts.title: Introducing the Orbital Conservation Institute
posts.author: Jamie Harper
posts.excerpt: The Orbital Conservation Institute was founded with a singular mission: to preserve the orbital environment for future generations through scientific research, policy development, and international cooperation.
posts.content:
The Orbital Conservation Institute (OCI) emerges at a critical juncture in humanity's relationship with space. As we witness unprecedented growth in satellite deployments, space tourism, and orbital infrastructure, the need for dedicated conservation efforts has never been more urgent.

Our mission extends beyond traditional space policy. We are committed to developing innovative solutions for orbital debris mitigation, sustainable space traffic management, and the preservation of critical orbital regions. Through rigorous scientific research and collaborative international frameworks, we aim to ensure that space remains accessible and usable for generations to come.

The Institute operates on three core pillars: Research Excellence, Policy Innovation, and Global Cooperation. Our research teams are developing cutting-edge technologies for debris tracking and removal, while our policy experts work closely with international bodies to establish comprehensive regulatory frameworks.

As we embark on our crucial mission, we invite the world and the global space community to join us in protecting our shared orbital heritage. The decisions we make today will determine whether future generations inherit a sustainable space environment or a cluttered, unusable orbital realm.

posts.title: The Iridium 33 and Cosmos 2251 Collision
posts.author: Jamie Harper
posts.excerpt: In 2009, two satellites—Iridium 33 and Cosmos 2251—collided in low Earth orbit in the first-ever accidental satellite-to-satellite crash. The incident created thousands of debris fragments and exposed serious weaknesses in space traffic coordination, international law, and debris mitigation practices. This event remains a stark reminder that Earth orbit is a fragile, shared environment—one that demands global responsibility, transparency, and active stewardship.
posts.content:
On February 10, 2009, at 16:56 UTC, two satellites collided at an altitude of approximately 789 kilometers over Siberia. This event marked the first-ever accidental collision between two intact satellites in orbit (NASA Orbital Debris Program Office, 2010).

The two satellites involved were Iridium 33, an active U.S. commercial communications satellite launched in 1997, and Cosmos 2251, a defunct Russian military satellite launched in 1993 and non-operational since 1995. Iridium 33 weighed around 560 kilograms, while Cosmos 2251 was approximately 900 kilograms (Wikipedia, 2009 Satellite Collision).

The satellites collided at a relative speed of roughly 11.7 kilometers per second, or about 42,120 kilometers per hour (CelesTrak Collision Report). Although warnings about a potential conjunction existed, the data used for tracking was too uncertain, and no evasive maneuver was made by Iridium. The impact occurred at nearly a right angle, creating a high-energy collision and a significant amount of orbital debris (Shepperd, AMOS 2023).

The collision created over 2,000 pieces of debris larger than 10 centimeters, as tracked by the U.S. Space Surveillance Network (NASA ODPO, 2010). Thousands more fragments too small to track also resulted.

Cosmos 2251 produced the majority of the debris, with over 1,600 cataloged fragments. Iridium 33 contributed around 600 tracked fragments. Some of this debris has already re-entered Earth's atmosphere, but many pieces are expected to remain in orbit for decades or longer, continuing to pose a collision risk to active satellites and crewed missions (NASA ODPO, 2020).

This event was a wake-up call for the global space community. It showed that orbital space, especially in low Earth orbit, is a limited and increasingly congested environment. The assumption that collisions were unlikely was proven dangerously wrong.

The collision also highlighted major legal and operational gaps. Since Cosmos 2251 was non-operational and there were no binding international norms regarding post-mission disposal at the time, no entity was held accountable under international space law (Columbia Law Review, 2023).

Iridium 33’s operators relied on public tracking data that underestimated the likelihood of a collision. This demonstrated a critical need for more accurate tracking, timely data sharing, and coordinated avoidance strategies.

In response to the collision, there was a renewed global push to improve space situational awareness and debris mitigation.

Government agencies and commercial operators began to cooperate more closely, sharing higher-quality ephemeris data and planning avoidance maneuvers more proactively. The event also led to stronger international guidelines around deorbiting defunct satellites and reducing debris generation (UN COPUOS, Space Debris Mitigation Guidelines).

Within hours of the collision, the debris began spreading across multiple orbits. Gabbard diagrams from the period show that the Iridium debris was pushed into both higher and lower orbits, while the Cosmos debris largely descended. Many of these fragments remain in orbit to this day (CelesTrak Event Analysis).

Even years later, fragments from this event continue to intersect with other operational orbits, increasing the long-term collision risk for active spacecraft (NASA ODPO).

The Iridium 33 and Cosmos 2251 collision is often cited in discussions about the Kessler Syndrome—a scenario in which cascading collisions cause an exponential increase in orbital debris (Donald Kessler, NASA, 1978). With the number of satellite launches now rapidly increasing, the lessons of this collision remain highly relevant.

Today, any serious discussion about orbital sustainability must account for the risks this event exposed. The need for responsible behavior in orbit, including proper end-of-life satellite disposal, real-time data sharing, and active debris removal, is more urgent than ever.

This was not just an unfortunate accident. It was a systemic failure—of coordination, transparency, and policy. The Iridium 33 and Cosmos 2251 collision forced the world to confront the reality that Earth orbit is a shared and fragile environment. Preserving its long-term utility requires collective responsibility, international cooperation, and technological innovation.

posts.title: Modelling the Orbital Commons
posts.author: Jamie Harper
posts.excerpt: To manage the orbital environment responsibly, we must treat it as a shared system with long-term, quantifiable risks. This article introduces a systems-based perspective on modelling orbital debris risk, incorporating environmental justice, economic equity, and multi-generational responsibility.
posts.content:
Earth orbit is not just a collection of satellites—it’s a dynamic, interconnected environment with limited capacity, governed by physics, economics, and policy decisions made across decades. Like climate change, the growth of orbital debris involves feedback loops, lagging consequences, and uneven vulnerabilities. To respond responsibly, we must understand orbit as a shared system: one that’s governed not just by what we do now, but by what we’ve already done—and by what others may do in the future.

A single fragmentation event—whether an accidental collision or an anti-satellite test—can send debris into unpredictable orbits, threatening spacecraft operated by other nations, companies, or researchers. But the risks aren’t just physical; they are also geopolitical and generational. Satellites supporting communications, weather forecasting, or climate monitoring may be disproportionately affected by orbital congestion or debris growth. Those with the fewest launches may suffer the most from irresponsible behavior in orbit.

To anticipate future risks, space agencies have developed models to simulate the evolution of the orbital environment. These include NASA’s LEGEND model, ESA’s MASTER model, and others designed to forecast how debris populations respond to different policies, such as improved end-of-life disposal, increased launch rates, or active debris removal.

These models show that debris growth is not linear—it can accelerate suddenly, especially in crowded altitude bands like sun-synchronous orbit. They also confirm the long-term benefits of even modest mitigation actions today. However, these tools are often closed-source or inaccessible to researchers and policymakers outside of major space agencies.

Like with climate models, orbital models are only as fair as the assumptions behind them. Most existing orbital risk assessments do not include equity-based scenarios—for example, how debris growth affects different regions' access to safe orbits, or how historic responsibility for debris compares to future harm.

For example, over 85% of cataloged debris was created by fewer than 10 spacefaring actors. Yet the impacts of that debris affect all satellite users, including emerging space nations with limited launch capacity. An equity-aware model would account for these dynamics—and help inform more just policy responses.

To truly govern the orbital commons, we need more inclusive, transparent, and equity-conscious modelling tools. These models should be open-access, interpretable by policymakers, and capable of integrating variables like economic development level, space infrastructure dependency, and long-term harm distribution. We also need shared global standards for defining what constitutes "safe" orbital use—and who gets to decide.

The orbital environment is not a vacuum of consequence. It’s a shared, finite resource, one that demands systems-level thinking to preserve.

posts.title: Cleaning Up Our Orbits
posts.author: Jamie Harper
posts.excerpt: As Earth orbit becomes increasingly polluted by defunct satellites and debris, simply tracking hazards is no longer enough. This article explores the emerging field of Active Debris Removal (ADR), the technologies behind it, and the legal and ethical questions we must answer to preserve orbital space for future generations.
posts.content:
The orbital environment is becoming increasingly crowded. Beyond the thousands of active satellites supporting communication, science, and climate monitoring, there are tens of thousands of defunct objects — dead satellites, spent rocket bodies, and fragments from past collisions. These objects remain in orbit, posing persistent and growing threats to operational spacecraft. As debris density increases, so does the risk of cascading collisions, potentially rendering entire orbital regions unusable. Preventing this outcome will require more than just improved monitoring. It demands action — specifically, the physical removal of debris. This is where active debris removal, or ADR, becomes essential.

Active debris removal refers to a suite of emerging technologies aimed at locating, approaching, capturing, and deorbiting non-functional objects in space. Unlike passive mitigation strategies, which focus on designing future missions to reduce their debris footprint, ADR targets existing hazards already in orbit. These are often large, intact, and relatively easy to track — but extremely difficult to remove. Debris removal typically involves sending a dedicated spacecraft to rendezvous with a defunct satellite or rocket stage and then either pushing it into a lower orbit where it will reenter and burn up in Earth's atmosphere, or moving it to a stable graveyard orbit.

There are many different approaches being explored. Some methods involve robotic arms designed to grapple onto debris targets. Others use nets, harpoons, tethers, or even ion beams to alter an object’s orbit. More experimental techniques include laser ablation, which uses focused energy to induce thrust on the target, and drag-enhancement devices like sails that accelerate atmospheric reentry. No single method will be sufficient — different debris types and orbital regimes require different solutions.

Despite the technical promise of ADR, the field faces serious challenges. The legal status of space debris is a major obstacle. Under the current framework of international space law, debris remains the property of the original launching state. That means even if a satellite is long defunct, no one else is legally allowed to remove it without permission. This raises complicated issues around liability, sovereignty, and trust. On top of the legal ambiguity, there is the question of cost. ADR missions are expensive, and there is currently no international funding mechanism or binding obligation that requires debris removal. With no financial return and no clear global enforcement, many actors are reluctant to invest in cleanup.

Technically, ADR is also extremely complex. Most debris objects were never designed to be captured. They may be tumbling, unstable, or lack any kind of docking mechanism. Capturing them safely requires precision navigation, autonomous control, and custom tools — all of which increase mission cost and risk. So far, most ADR demonstrations have been small-scale proof-of-concept missions, often involving cooperative targets.

Despite these barriers, several pioneering projects are laying the groundwork for future operational debris removal. The European Space Agency’s ClearSpace-1 mission plans to capture and deorbit a piece of space hardware using a robotic claw system. Astroscale’s ELSA-d mission tested magnetic docking between a servicing satellite and a dummy target, demonstrating key rendezvous capabilities. Other efforts like RemoveDEBRIS have tested net and harpoon systems in orbit. These are important first steps, but much more is needed.

ADR is not just a technological challenge — it’s a question of responsibility. The orbital environment is a shared global resource, but it is governed by fragmented policies and shaped by historic imbalances. Those who have contributed most to orbital pollution are not always the ones who will suffer its consequences. Just as the international community has begun to recognize the importance of climate remediation, so too must it prioritize orbital conservation. Active debris removal is not optional. It is essential to the sustainable use of space.
